facts.text: Appellant convicted under s. 307, Indian Penal Code and s. 19(f) of the Indian Arms Act by the Sessions Judge of Chatarpur.
Appellant sentenced to 10 years rigorous imprisonment under s. 307, Indian Penal Code and to 3 years rigorous imprisonment under s. 19(f) of the Indian Arms Act.
Appellant filed an appeal from jail which was summarily dismissed on merits on October 28, 1955.

On October 31, 1955, appellant filed a Memorandum of Appeal through a pleader which was rejected on November 1, 1955, on the ground that it was not maintainable owing to his appeal from jail under s. 420 of the Code of Criminal Procedure having been dismissed on October 28, 1955.

Appellant filed a petition before the Judicial Commissioner that the order dated October 28, 1955, dismissing his appeal from jail should be reviewed and his appeal should be reheard on merits. This petition was dismissed.
Appellant prayed for a certificate under Arts. 132 and 134(1)(c) of the Constitution. Judicial Commissioner opined no ground for Art. 134(1)(c) but granted certificate under Art. 132(1).
Court of Judicial Commissioner, Vindhya Pradesh, was a High Court for the purposes of the Code.

legal_issues.text: Whether s. 421 of the Code of Criminal Procedure offends against Art. 14 of the Constitution as it discriminates between a convicted person in jail filing appeal under s. 420 and one presenting appeal in person or through pleader under s. 419.
Whether the case involves a substantial question of law as to the interpretation of the Constitution warranting certificate under Art. 132(1).
Whether a second appeal through pleader is maintainable after summary dismissal of jail appeal under s. 420.

petitioner_arguments.text: S. 421 of the Code of Criminal Procedure offends against Art. 14 of the Constitution as it discriminates between convicted person in jail (whose appeal may be summarily dismissed without hearing) and convicted person who presents appeal in person or through pleader (who must be given reasonable opportunity of being heard).
Although appeal under s. 420 dismissed summarily, subsequent appeal through pleader ought to have been heard on merits; rejection without hearing violated s. 421.

court_reasoning.text: Scheme of Chapter XXXI CrPC: No appeal as of right except as provided; s.410 allows appeal from Sessions Judge to High Court; ss.419-420 provide manner of presentation (in person, through pleader, or from jail via authorities); s.421 allows summary dismissal if no sufficient grounds after perusal, but proviso requires hearing for s.419 appeals.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rational classification into three categories (in person, through pleader, from jail without pleader) with reasonable connection to object of providing appeals.

court_reasoning.text: No discrimination under s.410 as all convicted by Sessions Judge may appeal; difference in hearing based on mode of presentation justified as jail appellant cannot be heard in person or via pleader.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Proviso to s.421 does not offend Art.14.

court_reasoning.text: Order dismissing jail appeal on Oct 28, 1955 lawful and final under s.430; second appeal through pleader not maintainable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No substance in contention for second appeal; cases distinguished as none held second appeal maintainable after lawful dismissal.

holdings.text: S.421 CrPC, including proviso, does not offend Art.14; rational basis for classification.
No substantial question of law as to interpretation of Constitution.
Second appeal after lawful summary dismissal of jail appeal not maintainable under s.430 CrPC.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate granted under Art.132(1); issue of discrimination under Art.14

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Scheme of appeals; summary dismissal; finality; manner of presentation

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed holding that s.421 CrPC does not violate Art.14 of the Constitution due to rational classification in appeal procedures, summary dismissal of jail appeal was lawful and final, and no second appeal maintainable.

key_quotes.text: There is a rational basis for making the classification mentioned above which has a reasonable connection with the object of the legislation providing for appeals under Chapter XXXI.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning upholding s.421 against Art.14 challenge

key_quotes.text: It could not therefore be said that the proviso to s.421 offends against the provisions of Art.14 of the Constitution.
key_quotes.speaker: court
